title: Ticket #1108: Improving the locking situation of the logging systems
description:
The different logging systems have different file locking strategies for log file access and rotation. Some of them cause problems in shared file systems (such as NFS). The goal is to design the new unified logging system in a way, such that locking does not constitute a point of failure anymore.

A quick overview of the current locking strategies:

History files :
- write : No actual locking. Solely a reference counter assures that all started write processes will also be finished before closing. 

	- AppendHistory(ClassAd *)  // condor_c++_util/classadHistory.cpp
		-> OpenHistoryFile() // -- " --
		  -> safe_open_wrapper (if not open yet) + refCount increase
		-> fwrite
                -> RelinquishHistoryFile() : decrease of refCount after
		successfully finished write process
	 -  CloseHistoryFile() : makes sure that refCount is 0

- rotation : File is simply renamed. This assures that the file is closed at the time (therefore the last write process was finished; otherwise it wouldn't be closed, according to the close-file semantics) 

      - int rotate_file(const char *old_filename, const char *new_filename)
	( condor_util_lib/rotate_file.c )

dprintf :
- write : mutex/critical section for every write process; seems to have a queue for waiting messages

- rotation : rename of the old file; creation of a new one

Event-/User-Logs :
- write : Event file is opened with either locking en- or disabled. If enabled, a lock file is created that indicates that the file is accessed. If disabled, a fake lock will be created to simplify API usage; no effect on read/write access. 

	 ( condor_c++_util/write_user_log.cpp )
	 - WriteUserLog::openFile(  const char *file, bool log_as_user, bool
	   use_lock, bool append, FileLockBase *&lock, FILE *&fp )
	   -> uses condor_includes/file_lock.h API for creating a lock file
	   and managing thereof
	 - Write processes in WriteUserLog class obtain a WRITE_LOCK prior to
	   writing to the file.

- rotation : separate lock file (same API) as for "write". The lock file is already created in the Configure() process and cannot be turned off (makes sense). An actual lock status is obtained during the write process before rotation takes place (the actual rotation function does not deal with locking) and released after.

BENCHMARKS
average dprintf call with locking (personal Condor): 0.03 ms

Event logs (average) including write process (personal Condor) : 0.13 ms
(max values around 1 ms)

API suggestions
Essentially two options: either stick to integrated logging functions of one logging class or let a separate logging daemon handle all logging-related things.

(1) Logging daemon:

- Pro: Locking question becomes obsolete, because only one process will ever access file - Con: Daemon independence is not guaranteed; what happens if logging daemon is down?

Assumption: something like syslog will manage the logging itself; therefore it is possible to forward log messages to another host 

	Logd();
	Init(Type, Level, Location = NULL)
									   // whereas location could also be another host; NULL default means local
									   // Level is the max level that will be written (according to D_ALWAYS, D_FULLDEBUG, ... )
									   // Type: Which process requests logging (History, Daemon dprintf (Schedd, Shadow,...), EventLog...)


	int Write(Type, Level, Msg) // write message


	Read(...) // Read function .. will be more complex. TODO: Which args would be necessary?


	Close(Type) // Finishing log process

Open questions:
How to track number of log entries that will be discarded by deleting old log files in order to not exceed disk space?

How to prevent daemons from waiting for logd to come up or to stop working or to just discard log messages in case logd is failing?

(2) Integrated logging functions:

Problem: Locking needs to be taken care of -> how to avoid a) deadlocks, b) incompatibilities of different file systems/ interactions of different OS
